Incident Management for Network Services Incident Management for Network Services
draft-feng-opsawg-incident-management-00 draft-feng-opsawg-incident-management-01
Abstract Abstract
This document provides an architecture for the incident management This document introduces incident management solution and provides an
system and related function interface requirements. architecture and related function interface requirements for the
incident management system.
This document also defines a YANG module to support the incident This document also defines YANG modules to support the incident
lifecycle management. This YANG module is meant to provide a lifecycle management. The YANG modules are meant to provide a
standard way to report, diagnose, and resolve incidents for the sake standard way to report, diagnose, and resolve incidents for the sake
of enhanced network services. of enhanced network services.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
Network performance management and fault management are used for Network performance management and fault management are used for
monitoring and troubleshooting separately in networking monitoring and troubleshooting separately in networking
infrastructures. Typically, metrics and alarms, transaction infrastructures. Typically, metrics and alarms, transaction
operations are monitored centrally and incident tickets are triggered operations are monitored centrally and incident tickets are triggered
accordingly. A YANG [RFC7950] data model for alarm management accordingly.
[RFC8632] defines a standard interface for alarm management.

performance management. In addition, distributed tracing mechanism VPN Service Performance Monitoring[RFC9375] defines a standard

and debug operations, such as configuration transactions, across tracing mechanism defined in [W3C-Trace-Context] can also be used to
multiple distributed systems. follow, analyze and debug operations, such as configuration
transactions, across multiple distributed systems.

service-pm], trace context-centric solution is based on a data source solution are based on a data source specific information and
specific information and maintenance engineers' experience and fall maintenance engineers' experience and fall short when keeping track
short when keeping track of them separately in various different of them separately in various different management systems, e.g., the
management systems, e.g., the frequency and quantity of alarms frequency and quantity of alarms reported to Operating Support System
reported to Operating Support System (OSS) increased dramatically (in (OSS) increased dramatically (in many cases multiple orders of
many cases multiple orders of magnitude) with the growth of service magnitude) with the growth of service types and complexity, hard to
types and complexity, hard to aggregate in a single domain along with aggregate in a single domain along with key performance metrics,
key performance metrics, various different events, notifications, various different events, notifications, overwhelm OSS platforms,
overwhelm OSS platforms, result in low processing efficiency, result in low processing efficiency, inaccurate root cause
inaccurate root cause identification and duplicated tickets. identification and duplicated tickets. And, it is difficult to
assess the impact of alarms, performance metrics and other anomaly
data on network services.
Usually, the network modeling from device to different connection and Network devices are connected through various protocols and links to
service layers follows some existing standards. Once there are some form a network. Once a component is faulty or degraded, other
failures happened on network devices, there could be some correlative components related to the component will be affected, which will

to compress a series of alarms into fewer incidents. The traditional events. So,it is possible to compress a series of correlative

To address these challenges, an incident-centric solution is To address these challenges, an incident-centric solution is
proposed, which also supports cross-domain or cross-layer root cause proposed, which also supports cross-domain or cross-layer root cause
analysis and network troubleshooting. A network incident refers to analysis and network troubleshooting. A network incident refers to
an unexpected interruption of a network service, degradation of a an unexpected interruption of a network service, degradation of a
network service quality, or sub-health of a network service while an network service quality, or sub-health of a network service.
alarm described in [RFC8632] represents an undesirable state in a Different data sources including alarms, metrics and other anomaly
resource that requires corrective actions. An alarm will always be information can be aggregated into few amount of incidents by
reported when network resources are unexpected while an incident is correlation analysis and the impact of network services can be
reported only when network services are affected, e.g., symptoms assessed based on incidents. For example, the protocols related to
(e.g.,CPU overloaded) at the device level defined in [I-D.opsawg- the interface fail to work properly due to the interface down, many
service-assurance-yang] or root cause alarms can be used to generate alarms may be reported to upper layer management system and can be
and report incidents when the network service is in sub-health state aggregated into one incident, some network services may be affected
or gets degraded. An incident may be triggered by aggregation and by this incident (e.g. L3VPN services related with the interface
analysis of multiple alarms or other network anomalies, for example, will become unavailable). An incident may also be raised through the
the protocols related to the interface fail to work properly due to analysis of some network performance metrics, for example, as
the interface down, as a result, the network service becomes described in SAIN [I-D.ietf-opsawg-service-assurance-architecture],
unavailable. An incident may also be raised through the analysis of network services can be decomposed to some sub-services, some metrics
some network performance metrics, for example, the delay or packet are monitored for sub-services, symptoms will occur if services/sub-
loss rate exceeds the threshold, causing degradation of the network services are unhealthy(after analyzing metrics), these symptoms may
service. raise one incident, and it may cause degradation of the network
services.

important role in the processing of large amounts of data with important role in the processing of large amounts of data with

Figure 1: Incident Management Architecture Figure 1: Incident Management Architecture
Figure 1 illustrates the incident management architecture. Two key Figure 1 illustrates the incident management architecture. Two key
components for the incident management are incident management client components for the incident management are incident management client
and incident management agent. and incident management agent.
Incident management agent can be deployed in network analytics Incident management agent can be deployed in network analytics
platform, controllers or Orchestrators and provides functionalities platform, controllers and provides functionalities such as incident
such as incident detection, report, diagnosis, resolution, querying identification, report, diagnosis, resolution, querying for incident
for incident lifecycle management. lifecycle management.
Incident management client can be deployed in the network OSS or Incident management client can be deployed in the network OSS or
other business systems of operators and invokes the functionalities other business systems of operators and invokes the functionalities
provided by incident management agent to meet the business provided by incident management agent to meet the business
requirements of fault management. requirements of fault management.
A typical workflow of incident management is as follows: A typical workflow of incident management is as follows:
* Some alarms or abnormal operations, network performance metrics * Some alarms or abnormal operations, network performance metrics
are reported from the network. Incident management agent receives are reported from the network. Incident management agent receives
these alarms/abnormal operations/metrics and analyzes the impact these alarms/abnormal operations/metrics and try to analyze the
of these alarms on network services. If the analysis result correlation of them, if the incidents are identified, it will be
indicates that network services are affected, an incident will be reported to the client. The impact of network services will be
reported to the client. also analyzed and will update the incident.
* Incident management client receives the incident raised by agent, * Incident management client receives the incident raised by agent,
and acknowledge it. Client may invoke the 'incident diagnose' rpc and acknowledge it. Client may invoke the 'incident diagnose' rpc
to diagnose this incident to find the root causes. to diagnose this incident to find the root causes.
* If the root causes have been found, the client can resolve this * If the root causes have been found, the client can resolve this
incident by invoking the 'incident resolve' rpc operation, incident by invoking the 'incident resolve' rpc operation,
dispatching a ticket or using other functions (e.g. routing dispatching a ticket or using other functions (e.g. routing
calculation,configuration) calculation,configuration)
5. Functional Interface Requirements between the Client and the Agent 4.1. Cooperation with Alarm Management
5.1. Incident Detection +-----------------------------+
| OSS |
|+-------+ +-----------+ |
||alarm | | incident | |
||handler| | client | |
|+-------+ +-----------+ |
+---^---------------^---------+
| |
|alarm |incident
+---|---------------|---------+
| | controller | |
| | | |
|+--+---++ +-----------+ |
||alarm | | | |
||process+----->| incident | |
|| |alarm | agent | |
|+------++ +-----------+ |
| ^ ^ |

|alarm | metrics/trace/etc.
| |
+---+--------------+----------+
| network |
| |
+-----------------------------+
In alarm-centric solution, although alarms are processed (based on Figure 2: cooperation with alarm management
manual rules or preconfigured rule) before being sent to the network
OSS, multiple alarms are still sent to the network OSS. Whether YANG model for alarm management[RFC8632] defines a standard interface
these alarms have impact on network services and how much of the to manage the lifecycle of alarms. Alarms represent the undesirable
impact they created, it highly depends on the network OSS to analyze, state of network resources, alarm data model also defines the root
which affects the efficiency of network maintenance. causes and impacted services fields, but there may be lack of enough
information to determine them in lower layer system (mainly in
devices level), so alarms do not always tell the status of services
or the root causes. As described in [RFC8632], alarm management act
as a starting point for high-level fault management. While incident
management often works in network level, so it's possible to have
enough information to perform correlation and service impact
analysis. Alarms can work as one of data sources of incident
management and may be aggregated into few amount of incidents by
correlation analysis, network service impact and root causes may be
determined during incident process.
Incident also contains some related alarms,if needed users can query
the information of alarms by alarm management interface [RFC8632].
In some cases, e.g. cutover scenario, incident agent may use alarm
management interface [RFC8632] to shelve some alarms.
Alarm management may keep the original process, alarms are reported
from network to network controller or analytics and then reported to
upper layer system(e.g. OSS). Upper layer system may store these
alarms and provide the information for fault analysis (e.g. deeper
analysis based on incident).
Compared with alarm management, incident management provides not only
incident reporting but also diagnosis and resolution functions, it's
possible to support self-healing and may be helpful for single-domain
closed-loop control.
Incident management is not a substitute for alarm management.
Instead, they cooperate with each other to implement fault
management.
4.2. Cooperation with SAIN
+----------------+
| incident client|
+----------------+
^
|incident
+-------+--------+
| incident agent |
+----------------+
^
|symptoms
+-------+--------+

^
|metrics
+-------------+-------------+
| |

| |
+---------------------------+
Figure 3: cooperation with SAIN
SAIN [I-D.ietf-opsawg-service-assurance-architecture] defines the
architecture of network service assurance. A network service can be
decomposed into some sub-services, and some metrics can be monitored
for sub-services. For example, a tunnel service can be decomposed
into some peer tunnel interface sub-services and IP connective sub-
service. If some metrics are evaluated to indicate unhealthy sub-
services, some symptoms will occur. Incident agent may identify the
incident based on symptoms, and then report it to upper layer system.
So, SAIN can be one way to identify incident, services, sub-services
and metrics can be preconfigured via APIs defined by service
assurance YANG model [I-D.ietf-opsawg-service-assurance-yang] and
incident will be reported if symptoms match the condition of
incident.
4.3. Relationship with RFC8969
RFC8969[RFC8969] defines a framework for network automation using
YANG, this framework divides YANG modules into three layers, service
layer, network layer and device layer, and contains service
deployment, service optimization/assurance, and service diagnosis.
Incident works on network layer and aggregates alarms, metrics and
other information from device layer, it's helpful for service
assurance. And incident diagnosis may be one way of service
diagnosis.
4.4. Relationship with Trace Context
W3C defines a common trace context[W3C-Trace-Context] for distributed
system tracing, [I-D.rogaglia-netconf-trace-ctx-extension] defines a
netconf extension for [W3C-Trace-Context] and
[I-D.quilbeuf-opsawg-configuration-tracing] defines a mechanism for
configuration tracing. If some errors occur when services are
deploying, it's very easy to identify these errors by distributed
system tracing, and an incident should be reported.

Figure 2: Incident Detection Figure 4: Incident Identification
The incident management agent MUST be capable of detecting incidents. As described in Figure 4, multiple alarms, metrics, or hybrid can be
It can analyze the impact on network services from numerous alarms or aggregated into an incident after analysis.
monitor network service quality. Once the network service quality
does not meet expectations, the incident agent MUST report the
incident.
As described in Figure 2, multiple alarms, metrics, or hybrid can be The incident management agent MUST be capable of identifying
aggregated into an incident after analysis. Each incident is incidents. Multiple alarms, metrics and other information are
associated with network services. reported to incident agent, and the agent must analyze it and find
out the correlations of them, if the correlation match the incident
rules, incident will be identified and reported to the client.
Service impact analysis will be performed if an indent is identified,
and the content of incident will be updated if impacted network
services are detected.
AI/ML may be used to identify the incident. Expert system and online
learning can help AI to identify the correlation of alarms, metrics
and other information by time-base correlation algorithm, topo-based
correlation algorithm, etc. For example, if interface is down, then
many protocol alarms will be reported, AI will think these alarms
have some correlations. These correlations will be put into
knowledge base, and the incident will be identified faster according
to knowledge base next time.
As mentioned above, SAIN is another way to implement incident
identification. Observation timestamp defined in
[I-D.tgraf-yang-push-observation-time] and trace context defined in
[W3C-Trace-Context] may be helpful for incident identification.

5.2. Incident Diagnosis 5.2. Incident Diagnosis
After an incident is reported to the incident management client, the After an incident is reported to the incident management client, the

+---x incident-resolve +---x incident-resolve

+--:(success)
| +--ro success? empty

+--ro error-message? string

grouping root-cause-info { - incident diagnose: diagnose an incident instance.
description "The information of root cause."; - incident resolve: resolve an incident instance.
leaf cause-name {
type string;
description "the name of cause";
}
leaf detail {
type string;
description "the detail information of the cause.";
}
}
uses resources-info {
augment resource {
description "augment root cause information.";
//if root cause object is a resource of a node
uses root-cause-info;
}
}
//if root cause object is a node
uses root-cause-info;
}
}

description "This rpc can be used to acknowledge the specified
incidents.";
input {

}
description "the identifier of an incident instance.";
}

rpc incident-diagnose {
description "This rpc can be used to diagnose the specified
incidents. The result of diagnosis will be reported
by incident notification.";
input {
leaf-list incident-id {
type leafref {
path "/inc:incidents/inc:incident/inc:incident-id";
}
description
"the identifier of an incident instance.";
}
}
}
rpc incident-resolve {
description "This rpc can be used to resolve the specified
incidents. The result of resolution will be reported
by incident notification.";
input {
list incident {
key incident-id;
min-elements 1;
description "incident instances.";
leaf incident-id {
type leafref {
path "/inc:incidents/inc:incident/inc:incident-id";
}
description
"the identifier of an incident instance.";
}
}

Appendix A. Changes between revisions
[[RFC editor: please remove this section before publication.]]
v00 - v01
* Modify the introduction.
* Add the cooperation with alarm management.
* Add the cooperation with SAIN.
* Add the relationship with RFC8969.
* Add the relationship with observation timestamp and trace context.
* Clarify the incident identification process.
* Modify the work flow of incident diagnosis and resolution.
* Remove identities and typedefs from ietf-incident YANG module, and
create a new YANG module called ietf-incident-types.
* Modify ietf-incident YANG module, for example, modify incident-
diagnose rpc and incident-resolve rpc.
